overview: Support for Mortgage Interest (SMI) helps homeowners on certain benefits pay interest on loans or mortgages - what you'll get, eligibility and how to claim
title: Support for Mortgage Interest (SMI)

table.body:
If you're a homeowner getting certain income related benefits you may qualify for help towards your:

- mortgage interest payments on a loan taken out to buy your home
- interest payments on loans you have taken out for certain repairs and improvements to your home

This help is paid as part of your benefit and is called Support for Mortgage Interest (SMI).

You must be getting one of the following benefits:

- [Income Support](/income-support "Income Support")
- income-based [Jobseeker’s Allowance](/jobseekers-allowance "Jobseeker's Allowance")
- income-related [Employment and Support Allowance](/employment-support-allowance "Employment and Support Allowance")
- [Pension Credit](/pension-credit "Pension Credit")  

^There's no guarantee that you will get SMI for a loan you take out^

SMI is normally paid direct to your lender.

*[SMI]: Support for Mortgage Interest
table.title: Overview

table.body:
##Changes to Support for Mortgage Interest (SMI)##

Different rules applied to SMI up to 5 January 2009. If you were getting help towards your mortgage interest payments before 5 January 2009, you will continue to get help up to the same limit on your mortgage or loan. This is usually up to £100,000.
 
##Rules that apply to SMI from 5 January 2009##
 
From 5 January 2009, if you were getting:

- Income Support
- income-based Jobseeker’s Allowance
- income-related Employment and Support Allowance

most claims would get help with interest payments on mortgage or loans up to £200,000.
 
From 5 January 2009, those getting SMI up to £200,000 can keep this higher limit if they move onto Pension Credit within 12 weeks of stopping their claim to:

- [Income Support](/income-support "Income Support")
- income-based [Jobseeker’s Allowance](/jobseekers-allowance "Jobseeker's Allowance")
- income-related [Employment and Support Allowance](/employment-support-allowance "Employment and Support Allowance")

##How SMI is paid##

SMI is normally paid direct to your mortgage lender 13 weeks after you've claimed benefit - this is known as a waiting period.

If you’re getting [Pension Credit](/pension-credit "Pension Credit"), there’s no waiting period before SMI is paid.

##How SMI is calculated##

The standard interest rate used to calculate SMI is currently 3.63%.

##What’s not included## 

SMI can’t help you pay:

- the amount you borrowed - only the interest on your mortgage is paid
- anything towards insurance policies you have 
- mortgage arrears

##Time limits##

A 2 year time limit for SMI applies to new claimants getting income-based Jobseeker’s Allowance. This was introduced from 5 January 2009.

If you've been getting SMI as part of your income-based [Jobseeker’s Allowance](/jobseekers-allowance "Jobseeker's Allowance") claim for 2 years from 5 January 2009 or later, you will no longer receive help with your mortgage interest as long as you remain in receipt of benefit. This applies if you have been getting SMI continually or through linked benefit claims.

It's important that you talk to your lender about this change. Lenders are required to treat people fairly, and must consider what they can do to prevent borrowers losing their homes.

There’s no limit to how long you can get SMI if you’re getting:

- [Income Support](/income-support "Income Support")
- income-related [Employment and Support Allowance](employment-support-allowance "Employment and Support Allowance") 
- [Pension Credit](/pension-credit "Pension Credit") 

*[SMI]: Support for Mortgage Interest
